amount of time that youyou guys have are spending with me and and the enthusiasm
that you you have first H maker and hopefully this will be a useful bit of
time that you spend with me so overall I want to talk about some of the DevOps
challenges that people encounter in machine learning in general not not necessarily related to to stage maker or
AWS and part of the reasons for the genesis of those those challenges and
and then we can talk a little bit about sage maker what customers say about it
in in AWS we typically like to illustrate these things through customer

is and then I'll talk about how sage maker can be used as part of a portfolio
of services that you would use to address those DevOps challenges and then
I'd like to take some questions I know we're running a little late overall between this talk and and the talk on
automatic model tuning that's coming up later I'll try and get you guys out of here by 1:00 so we can have lunch on
time so let's go ahead and and dive in and talk about some of the challenges
that people encounter when they're trying to operationalize machine learning because really that's the thing
that that I'm focused on as as the sage maker product owner and it's something
that I think is very critical in general if we how many of you have seen this
slide before only a few of you okay great so in general machine learning the
machine learning process is pretty hard there's a lot of stages that you go through it's something that is very
unique to machine learning and is not by the rest of software development which means that it's even harder
because there are no processes set up around it first and and the reason for
that is because it's primarily machine learning originated out of data science experimentation so the way people think
about this is as a science experiment how do I experiment how do I do this one-off and then at the end of it I get
a model what you do with that model who knows right there's a model and that's
the way people have traditionally thought about it so you end up with a lot of these non repeatable heavy
lifting processes first at the initially you try and set up an environment where you can safely store your data and be
able to analyze that data process that data and so on and that generally ends
up taking a bit of time as you try and secure the environment sometimes it's the data scientists laptop ideally it's
something that's a little more secure than that and can't be lost at an airport and so on but you you set up
this environment you load in the tools you get it set up exactly right so that
you have the drivers all lined up this software all lined up I actually in the
past I've I've set up an environment like this it's taken me hours to make sure that all of the driver versions
compiled into the software as well as installed on the on the Box are the same
it ends up taking somewhere between hours and weeks to set up this environment and then there's a challenge
around labeling the data so you you have a bunch of data it's usually dirty in some way or the other
it's non-uniform you need people to pre-process it you need to be able to add annotation to that so it has the
labels that you need in order to answer the machine learning question so then a couple of weeks have gone by you finally
got your environment you're ready to process through it and then you say okay
I'm ready to start training and initially if you've got small data you take a sample of the data and you train
and you're like okay I've got this this trained model I think it'll work well on
a bigger set of data and in order to work on that bigger set of data I'm gonna try and use a cluster
for it and that's hard setting up a distributed cluster to do machine
learning training is hard time-consuming in fact it's so hard that a lot of the
customers that I've talked to end up leaving their clusters up and running paying for it the entire time 24/7 and
then they have a priority queue that says certain jobs need to be prioritized over others and and and so on in order
to make sure that they're utilizing that cluster correctly it's it's a mess scaling up and and making these
algorithms work is really hard and then once you have this model you need to put it into an application because the model
itself does no good to anybody unless it's incorporated into an application so they take that model and hand it over to
DevOps at that point and you look at it and you're like what do I do with this model it's not going to meet any of my
operational characteristics so you end up with this cycle that takes anywhere
between 6 and 18 months in order to get this model into production and part of
the challenge is that machine learning tools are different than the ones that are traditionally used by DevOps
audiences so you have a set of things like anaconda and scikit-learn and some
of those are that are the easier tools to use and then you have deep learning tools that are pretty sophisticated hard
to get right have a lot of adjustments that you need to do and I'm not even
talking about things like MPI and Avadh which are really truly hard to get set up right and then you have SPARC and
and there's even a set of things like Apache airflow and ml flow where people
are trying to develop these machine learning specific tools to help with the operationalization of machine learning
and part of that is because the ml challenges are different than the DevOps
challenges when you talk about DevOps you have a whole set of things around is the software compliant is it in the
right regions can we audit it can we look at the security of it is actually
maintaining the security of the data when it's a one-off experiment you don't need to think about these things when
you're doing this day after day in a repeatable process all of these things become important is it portable can I
actually take that that application and move it to different environments if I need it can I take the model from iOS to
Android so that I can develop an Android app can I take it from on-premises to the cloud or you know essentially you
need to be able to move it around and all of that needs to be done in an environment where it's always up and
running so it's one thing if you're doing this one-off but if it's something
that you're building a business on it needs to be up and running all the time and that's a different challenge altogether and then if you're successful
you're lucky then you need to scale it out so that it takes your your peak
loads and all of these are different challenges than the machine learning challenges that we talked about so what
happens is DevOps and gets involved too late this is really the root of the problem the scientists are will work on
these small data sets and then they say okay I'm good it might be pretty clean
so I'll have a data engineer clean up that data for me so that it works well
for machine learning it's not necessarily a production ready process so it may be done in a non repeatable
way and you end up doing this in a very dedicated environment that is separate
from the production environment so these science project things get tossed over
the wall and DevOps doesn't know how to implement them in production and then all of this all of the DevOps challenges
are something of an afterthought and what ends up happening is that it
doesn't end up being as useful in production as it was in the science
experiment so everyone ends up being disappointed with this entire process it
took too long it ended up in production way too late and the results were not great so what
is sage maker I usually talk about sage maker in the context of the overall AWS
ml stack because we're not trying to sage maker itself isn't the silver
bullet solution for all of your ml problems we believe that there is this entire spectrum of needs that you have
and we have different services to meet different needs within your organization the AI services the top layer of the
stack here those services are the easy to use I'm not I have this problem that
I know machine learning can help with Amazon help me with solving these
problems pick out pick out objects from images or recognize entities from blocks
of unstructured text that kind of thing where these are common problems across a lot of industries and Amazon has good
expertise to bring in order to make that easy so that AI services are actually the
easiest to use out-of-the-box but then there's a set of problems that is unique
to your business what is a unique value that you can provide to your customers that you want to develop that you
believe is the core of your business so in order to help with that our goal
is to make it so that you can bring your data in that you can develop expertise in in that area and that you can
operationalize it and that's where sage maker fits in and this is built on a foundation of a lot of open source
projects that we contribute to that we participate in this whole community is something that we are dedicated to
making a difference in and this foundation is is what it's built on top
of this along with things like Intel based compute Nvidia based GPUs of a
strong storage infrastructure that infrastructure layer is what enables us
to provide services that enable you to move quickly so the goal here is that
this is your quickest path from idea to production I've personally been involved
in machine learning projects where it took me six months to go from the the
data science telling me hey this is this is working out really well against historical data let's push it into
production six months later it gets into production this is not the way to do machine learning machine learning builds
on machine learning you learn more as you go along it's iterative you need to be able to push things into production
within days to weeks at at worst weeks at worst so sage maker is intended to
help you push things into your production environment and how the sage
maker do it it it basically helps you with all of the challenges that I
outlined through the entire cycle or it tries to help with a lot of these
challenges so you have these notebook environments that are customizable that
integrate together which are with your git repository so you're bringing the
data scientist into the rest of the DevOps ecosystem in that way it has built-in security features it uses the
AWS virtual private cloud and private link it encrypts the storage using a
customer provided key so it maintains the security of the data it's something
that you can feel confident that if you use these environments that your data is held securely it provides you with
automatic cluster setup and teardown it provides you with algorithms that you can use to get started it provides you
with frameworks there's an AWS marketplace for machine learning in
which you can purchase the work of other people and use those algorithms as well so the idea there is you would be able
to get up and running as quickly as possible why will you develop your own expertise in the area it provides
automatic model tuning which is something that we'll talk about in our in our next time together after this
talk is over and it provides this in a way like because it provides cluster
setup and teardown it actually provides you with a lower cost solution than the solutions
that people usually use which is this persistent cluster that runs regardless of whether you're actually doing machine
learning training or not instead of having that persistent cluster you can spin up and spin down and it provides
you with a good way to reduce costs there as well the next if you look at
how it gets deployed again it lets you set up these clusters on demand you only
pay for they the instances that are up and running which means that you are
having reduced cost there as well and it has integrated auto scaling which means
it can scale up to meet your peak demand and scale down as well it's integrated
with cloud watch for monitoring and it has features that allow you to optimize
for hardware as well so Sage maker neo will compile a model for a specific
hardware target and we provide elastic inference which will further reduce the
cost on the inference side and this is something that intuitive is one of the
early customers that has realized a lot of benefit with Sage maker first they
moved one model over and then they said wow this is going really great and in
the in the next I think the first model took them six months to move over and
then they moved another five over and I think that took roughly six months to
move over and then they're they're moving another 25 over so if you look at the way these things progress they're
able to move a lot quicker and they're able to develop these models much much
faster than they were able to prior to Sage maker what I what I heard from the Intel folks
when I talked to them at at at reinvent is that they were able to bring their
model development time from over six months down to less than two weeks which
is amazing if you think about it this is the kind of thing that you need to be able to do if you're building a machine
learning company you need to be able to do these things in a repeatable fashion and you need to do them fast and if you
look at at Intuit this is a this is a company that deals with I want to say something
like sixty percent of the u.s. the u.s. is tax data so they have a very very
high bar for security they're very concerned about things like fraud and they're able to put their critical
critical machine learning problems on Sage maker and they're able to run
faster as a result so part of what sage maker provides is
this notion of modularity and this notion of being able to choose exactly
how you want to use Sage maker and a lot of data scientists and machine learning
scientists are very particular about the way they work and they want to use their own tools they want to use the
environment that they're familiar with and the reason for that is because they're solving really hard problems so
if you say hey you know what I'm gonna give you a toolset and you have to use this tool set and you have to solve
these really difficult problems it becomes a double challenge so instead what we decided was we built sage maker
in a way that it works with the data scientists it works with the way you work so if they want to use this the
hosted the the hosted notebook instances on on Sage maker those are there if they
want to use their own laptop that works too you can still use it from your own laptop you can use it from Sparky you
can use it I actually have one customer who's who's using their entire machine
learning workflow workflow is from the console which is a little surprising to me but you know we provide this because
we think they're useful even for small numbers of customers and we're trying to
make it so that you build it your own way similarly for training we want it to
work the way that you want to work with zero setup we want it to be so that you
can use a built-in algorithm so you can use the marketplace algorithms if you feel like you have IP that you would
want to share with other people and you'd want to be able to monetize it you can even use the marketplace as a way that you can
publish your own work and provide others with a way that they can easily use your
your IP in-house we also work with all frameworks so we have example containers
that we've provided for tensorflow for MX net for pi torch for chainer
it's not limited to those all of those containers we've even open sourced them so if you want to take them and fork
them and develop your own in-house docker containers you can do that or I
mean essentially you can use docker for your own custom algorithms and you can bring your own expertise in your own IP
and still use sage maker in in all of the ways that I describe I'll just talk
a little bit briefly about about the built-in algorithms the built-in algorithms are nice for traditional
machine learning problems because they're built for really high scale and built for reliability and it's the
quickest way to get started with with things like you know linear regression
or gradient boosted trees or the like and the it really doesn't it isn't
necessary to have multiple implementations of of linear regression
or PCA or k-means there there really is a very few efficient implementations of
that so as a result we've provided a set of I think it's up to 18 now built-in
built-in algorithms that you can use for various problems to everything from the general-purpose to things like a
sequence to sequence language focused ones object detection semantic segmentation for for images and we even
launched IP insights which helps you with login anomaly detection in the
security space so the idea there is we'll provide you with a good set of built-in algorithms and the marketplace
will provide you with additional algorithms that you can use even if you don't have that expertise Union house
and then you can deploy your own ways well you can deploy into into sage maker
and I'll talk a little bit later about about the deployment methods but
essentially you can even bring your bottle in from outside of sage maker if you chose to train in the sage maker
notebook or if you chose to train in SPARC I have customers that are training
in their own on-premises spark clusters and they say this deployment part of
sage maker is is really useful for us so we'll just use deployment sage maker is
is the set of loosely coupled services that you can use in order to help you
speed up your machine learning workflow we're not going to say you must use all of the sage maker components in order to
get use out of it and and similarly you can also automatically tune models the
one thing that I want to call out here is that you can automatically tune models that you brought yourself so even
if you brought in a docker container with your own secret sauce algorithm you can still use it for hyper parameter
tuning so the goal here is that we want
to make common development tools easier to use for ml we want to make a docker
easy so for the most part even though docker is the underlying technology that
we use for a lot of sage maker data scientists don't really need to know how
to interact with docker in order to use sage maker for that purpose similarly we announced git integration
and and I can demo that shortly we announced git integration that allows
the data scientist to work with git and one of one of my my customers said we
have we just had a data scientist consultant start with us and she for the
for the life of her won't use git she can't figure out how to use use git she

it comes time to operationalize these we integrated together with step step functions and and Apache airflow so that

integrations with other services and then it also integrates with Auto scale
and and monitoring and logging so that you can use that in the same way that you use other AWS services so let me

enable or disable internet access and all of the traffic from this to my V PC
because I've specified a subnet and I've specified a V PC at instance creation
all of this traffic will go through Amazon networks none of the traffic goes through the public internet as long as
I'm accessing private link endpoints which is a really big plus for companies
that are dealing with sensitive data financial data healthcare data government data that kind of thing so if

notebook view and it goes straight into into Jupiter lab which is I guess they

scientists are very used to this is the kind of thing that they work with on a

committed changes very easily you can stage the changes for commit so if I put

can stay in this environment and they're not forced to switch between tools that

this
so again we look at we look at these
develops challenges I briefly mentioned them how does sage maker work in order to
address these challenges to start with for compliance and audit AWS have used
this as a shared responsibility between you guys and and us so we will maintain
the compliance of the cloud and you maintain compliance in the cloud and
that's the way that we look at it so as part of that there are certain services
that are in scope for several compliance regimes for sage maker in particular
we're in scope for ISO we're in scope for PCI DSS we're in scope for for sock
one two and three and we are compatible with gdpr and and HIPAA for those that
deal with healthcare data and and ITAR as well which is sort of a more US
specific thing this is a list that continually grows this is a list that
we're trying to make sure that we have our compliant with various regimes and
part of this is because we know this is important for operationalization like it's great if it's a science experiment
if it's a one-off usually you can get your internal people to sign off on something that's internal only in an
experiment but when it comes time to production you actually have to make sure that you're adhering to the
appropriate laws when it comes to dealing with theá-- we're in a similar fashion we're
available in in 14 different regions including India which is something that
we launched in in November we're continuing to be aggressive about regional expansion we know that's
something that's that's important for people who deal with data that has to stay within the borders the the goal is
that you would be able to use sage maker for all of these these types of problems and we integrate automatically with AWS
croute the cloud trail which means that you have an audit log of all of these actions being recorded in a place that's
convenient to work with for compliance purposes another thing that we've spent
a great deal of effort on is security because the data that people usually
want to do machine learning with I've had customers that that come to me usually the first thing that they say is
we want to put business critical data and do machine learning with our business critical data frankly that's
not what I would recommend starting out with I would recommend starting out with something that's a little easier and
doesn't have as many challenges as your business critical data but that's clearly where customers want to get and
because it's business critical data it's it's the data that is most crucial to your business we want to make sure that
we're acting as good stewards and providing the appropriate level of
security for that so we we do things like sage maker itself doesn't store
data except for intermediate data and ground truth and an in-ear media data
within things like like training and so
on we don't persist that data the data gets persisted in your account under
your control encrypted with your key and this is important because we we don't
retain any control of the data we don't retain any data we actually provide all
of that data back to you put it in your account so you can control it delete it do whatever is
needed in order to manage your own internal policies so you manage the
lifecycle of the data and all of the artifacts everything that is associated with it and because of that we we don't retain
permission to the data either so in order to have permission to access your
data in order to use your your docker containers and so on you pass in a role
you pass into an iamb role to Sage makers so sage maker has that permission
for as long as we hold hold on to the I am role and then once the operation is
done once training is done or once we're done with auto-scaling we toss that role away so that we
longer have permissions to that data we also don't use shared instances so the
instances that we use are dedicated to you and that that means that relative to
some of the attacks that we've seen meltdown inspector and so on earlier in
the year that's not something that's as much of a concern because those instances aren't being shared we also if
you specify a key that you manage we use that key for encryption at rest we
encrypt all of the artifacts including the model artifacts if you specify a key
for that we encrypt those and you may ask why the model artifacts because is
that really important to encrypt and what I would say to you is there there
are these attacks that are model inversion attacks that can potentially regenerate some of the data based on
taking the model and having some of the data available they're able to regenerate some of the other data these
these are attacks that are pretty sophisticated and sort of Nation
attacked and researchy attacks at this point but at the same time when you start putting this production models
into production and you put business critical data into production we want to make sure that you have the tools that
you need in order to secure all of the information including the model artifacts and then in transit we use we
we use TLS between all of the components that we have we we also support virtual
private clouds which means that none of this none of this data will go over the
public Internet we encrypt it but we also give you the ability to make sure
that none of this data goes over the public Internet so it's encrypted even within the Amazon Network and we support
we support private link so that when you access those those jupiter' notebook
instances you can access them through your V PC so even that data doesn't go through the public internet and
and so on so we treat this as something that is critical to provide you the
tools with so that you can operationalize machine learning it's not a one-off experiment it's something that
you need to be able to do repeatedly it's something that you need to have templates for to create this environment
is something that you need to customize for your environment and be able to when
a data scientist gets on-boarded into your organization be able to say here's your notebook instance you can get up
and running quickly and we know this is an environment that has the tools for you is secure to use with the data that you
need to access so that you can get up and running we also give you the ability
to configure the notebooks so that they don't have internet access and and so on in order to make it a truly sequestered
environment so the next thing is we have
heard from quite a few customers that they're looking for portability between
environments some of the applications that they have are appropriate for Sage maker and some are not and some need to
run in on-premises for business reasons these are things that we want to enable and yes we're we're very happy if we're
able to serve you with with sage maker hosting and in the cloud but that's the same time we know that there are
business considerations that make it such that not every workload is able to run that way so sage makers is designed
in a way that lends itself to portability it uses docker containers those docker containers the ones where
we produce our open sourced the libraries that we produce whether it's the Python library that you can use on
your on your desktop or in the notebook instances the Python libraries are open source the SPARC library is open source
we really want to produce an environment that allows you to seamlessly move from
environment to environment as your business dictates we re believe that a
large part of it is best in the cloud but at the same time if you have business constraints that make it so
that you can't use the cloud for everything we still want to enable your business so we we've
designed things to allow you to be able to take advantage of some of our work even in other environments and we also
deploy with availability in mind so AWS in in general has multiple availability
zones per region and we automatically deploy into multiple availability zones
in order to maintain high availability and of course just like everything else we monitor the infrastructure in order
to make sure that everything is up and running and and work seamlessly so the
last challenge that I want to talk about is is scalability and this is one of
those challenges that you only encounter once you're in a production environment which is why it becomes much more of a
challenge that's the point at which if if you go with the toss the model over
the fence kind of approach you end up with stuff like this where you know how do you operationalize
it if you have this kind of spiky workload and it wasn't designed with
that in mind the way we do it is we provide integration with AWS application
auto scaling and you can basically set the min and Max instances you can set
the number of target invitations so that you're able to say each instance we
believe it should be able to take this many invitations I think we recommend
that you use scale-up at at 50% of the max invitations so that you have a
little bit of buffer and it'll scale up at the point at which you choose so once
you actually see this in action you essentially see the the load go up and
once auto scaling kicks in when it's above that threshold you see the number
of invitations per instance actually goes down because you transitioned over to the point where you have an
additional instance in this particular case I think we transition from from one to two instances so it's pretty dramatic
in in most cases if you actually look at a product work load it's not going to be that
dramatic it's going to drop a little but because you're already running at scale and you're just adjusting the number of
instances to suit the traffic it won't be quite this dramatic the the reason
the reason we chose the the scaling criteria as as the typical scaling
criteria as being invocation per second per instance is because there's a great
deal of non uniformity between the requirements of each of these algorithms
there's different memory requirements different CPU different GPU requirements all of that kind of thing which means
that essentially the indications seems to be the lowest common denominator
scaling parameter that you can use of course if you develop your own custom
algorithms and you'e meant to cloud wash you can actually use those there's no particular restriction on what scaling
parameter you can use we can consume anything based on on the instances CloudWatch metrics but because we wanted
to provide a pattern that could easily be used by you we we chose the invitations per second and if you look
at the way that these are are specified it's actually specified in a in a pretty
simple format you just register the scaleable target and you provide the
parameters for scaling min and Max instances and that kind of thing and
then you provide the policy that you would use in order to make it scale on
in this case number of invitations per second so if you scale by utilization in
this way this is this is essentially the way that that the scaling works out so
if you look at a sage maker sage maker
itself we also provide you with a number of options for deploying I've talked a
bit about some of the really the scalability characteristics are mostly centered around real time deployment but
that's only one the options that you can use for deployment and it isn't necessarily the right one for all of the business use
cases which is why we provide you with multiple options for doing that you have
real-time deployment but you also have batch transformation we integrate
together with Greengrass ml which allows you to deploy two devices you can even
take the model artifacts out and you can deploy them straight to devices using your own pipeline I know there's there's
customers I have customers like GE Healthcare who deploy to x-ray machines
I mean you can't really expect Greengrass to be running on on their x-ray machine so they have their own
deployment pipeline that they use they have their own processes around that but they're still able to use sage maker for
training and they're still able to operationally deploy it to all of their devices using that and you can even
deploy on whatever local environment you want because all of those artifacts all
of the results of training are in your account they're fully under your control you can do whatever you like with them
at that point you're not locked into sage maker so the the two options that
are built into sage maker are real time and and batch batch transformation batch
transformation is something that we launched in July real time we had it at launch in in November of 2017
there's two different really two different use cases for that you can get
some of the goodness of both of those cases depending on on what your business use cases some customers actually will
do things like if the data doesn't change over the course of a day and they
still want low latency characteristics they'll do things like batch transformation loaded into dynamodb and
then use use that dynamo jeebies low latency access time in order to pull in
the inferences so you can do things like that in order to address some of the use
cases both of these are similar in the
way that they work they use similar containers and part of that is an advantage as well because if you actually look at how data
scientists work data scientists typically end up working in a lot of batch environments they don't have a lot
of real time because if you think about real time as an ocean that's something
that's a production characteristic so when they're working on historical data they don't really have this notion of
real time it's a little strange to set up a real time endpoint and then feed things to it in batch so the advantage
of using this type of environment and using an environment in which you have the same docker container in both
real-time and batch is that when the data scientist works on this in a batch
environment they're able to take that same container and then as a DevOps engineer you can deploy that same
container into real time and then you don't have a discrepancy between the
environment in which the data scientists are working and the environment in which you're you're going into production just
briefly talking about the benefits of batch transform it's pretty low cost and
it's pay-as-you-go because sage maker just like for training will setup and teardown the
clusters you don't have any persistent instances and during the course of time
when you're actually doing inferences because of the embarrassingly parallel nature of inferences you end up with
very very high utilization which also contributes to lower cost for inferences
of course if you need real-time and if you need that lowly and see a response you can also use a sage maker in these
real-time environments I'll kind of skip over this this is the way that you would
configure a real-time endpoint briefly
talking about how you would update an endpoint because again this is a
production environment so when it's integrated together with your application you don't necessarily want
